item.title: Bleak add a quote by Vladimir Nabokov
item.description: "I would like to spare the time and effort of hack reviewers and, generally, persons who move their lips when reading." -- Vladimir Nabokov

item.title: Bleak add a quote by Oscar Wilde
item.description: "Most people are other people. Their thoughts are someone else's opinions, their lives a mimicry, their passions a quotation." -- Oscar Wilde

item.title: Bleak add a quote by Ambrose Bierce
item.description: "The covers of this book are too far apart." -- Ambrose Bierce

item.title: Bleak add a quote by G.K. Chesterton
item.description: "Poets have been mysteriously silent on the subject of cheese." -- G.K. Chesterton

item.title: Bleak add a quote by G.K. Chesterton
item.description: "To have a right to do a thing is not at all the same as to be right in doing it." -- G.K. Chesterton

item.title: Bleak add a quote by Max Beerbohm
item.description: "Our hero's unreasoning rage was fed by a not unreasonable jealousy. It was clear to him that Zuleika had forgotten his existence. To-day, as soon as he had killed her love, she had shown him how much less to her was his love than the crowd's. And now again it was only the crowd she cared for. He followed with his eyes her long slender figure as she threaded her way in and out of the crowd, sinuously, confidingly, producing a penny from one lad's elbow, a threepenny-bit from between another's neck and collar, half a crown from another's hair, and always repeating in that flute-like voice of hers: "Well, this is rather queer!" -- Max Beerbohm

item.title: Bleak add a quote by Marguerite Yourcenar
item.description: "Passion such as hers is all consent, asking little in return. I had merely to enter a room where she was to see her face take on that peaceful expression of one who is resting in bed. If I touched her, I had the impression that all the blood in her veins was turning to honey." -- Marguerite Yourcenar

item.title: Bleak add a quote by Edith Wharton
item.description:
"She said she knew we were safe with you, and always would be, because once, when she asked you to, you'd given up the thing you most wanted."
Archer received this strange communication in silence. His eyes remained unseeingly fixed on the thronged sunlit square below the window. At length he said in a low voice: "She never asked me." -- Edith Wharton

item.title: Bleak add a quote by Henry James
item.description: "Three things in human life are important: the first is to be kind; the second is to be kind; and the third is to be kind." -- Henry James

item.title: Bleak add a quote by Clive James
item.description: "Common sense and a sense of humor are the same thing, moving at different speeds. A sense of humor is just common sense, dancing." -- Clive James

item.title: Bleak add a quote by Samuel Johnson
item.description: "I never desire to converse with a man who has written more than he has read." -- Samuel Johnson

item.title: Bleak add a quote by Montaigne
item.description: "No-one is exempt from speaking nonsense â€“ the only misfortune is to do it solemnly." -- Montaigne

item.title: Bleak add a quote by S.J. Perelman
item.description: "I guess I'm just an old mad scientist at bottom. Give me an underground laboratory, half a dozen atom-smashers, and a beautiful girl in a diaphanous veil waiting to be turned into a chimpanzee, and I care not who writes the nation's laws." -- S.J. Perelman

item.title: Bleak add a quote by Peter De Vries
item.description: "Everybody hates me because I'm so universally liked." -- Peter De Vries

item.title: Bleak add a quote by Peter De Vries
item.description: "Life is a zoo in a jungle" -- Peter De Vries

item.title: Bleak add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "At the age of eleven or thereabouts women acquire a poise and an ability to handle difficult situations which a man, if he is lucky, manages to achieve somewhere in the later seventies." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Bleak add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "Freddie experienced the sort of abysmal soul-sadness which afflicts one of Tolstoy's Russian peasants when, after putting in a heavy day's work strangling his father, beating his wife, and dropping the baby into the city's reservoir, he turns to the cupboards, only to find the vodka bottle empty." -- P.G. Wodehouse
